column7: Primal oneness encompasses all.\nIt is profound.
column8: Primal oneness\nThis is the correct state of contemplation.

column7: Spiritual forces war in darkness,\nDeploying yin and yang for battle.
column8: Spirits warring in the dark\nThere good and evil are juxtaposed.

column7: The dragon emerges at the center,\Its head and tail stretch forth,\nFit for use.
column8: It reveals its creativity.

column7: Lowliness, emptiness, nothingness, compliance.\nDespite a full portion of nature and Decree,\nHe is still blocked.
column8: He cannot receive in full.

column7: When the sun is centered in the sky,\nUse this time to become a master.
column8: The noble man merits his place.

column7: The moon losing its fulness\nIs not as good as new light in the west.
column8: Ignoble men are the first to retreat.

column7: Fully matured:\nFire stores what nutures.\nWater embraces rectitude.
column8: Embracing the fully ripe\nIs the rule for employing subjects.

column7: When yellow is not yellow,\nIt overturns the norms of autumn.
column8: He lacks the virtue of the center.

column7: When souls are overturned,\nCh'i and form revert.
column8: Time is not overcome.

column7: Returning to the heart of Heaven,\nIn what virtue does he err?\nThe Way is blocked.
A pivot set directly center\nSweeps full circle, not in angles.
What I give out and what I take in\nAre chief factors in good luck or ill.
He is girded by hook and belt,\nOn which is tied a ring of jade.
He dwells at the center of the land,\nAnd there sets his golden carriage.\nHeaven's warnings increase.
Good faith encircles his integrity\nAnd penetrates to Heaven above.
Greatly immoral men, seeing their peers,\nReturn to cover.
Turning out faults from the self,\nMisfortunes will not be great.
As he returns to ruin,\nSome reject him and walk away.
Yellow, pure and in hiding,\nIts boundaries are unseen,\nStored away, pent-up in the Springs.
The yellow is impure,\nBent at the root.
The rosy babe is lifted up\nSo that original purity\nWill have its rightful end.
Pulling out our faults\nIs not possible by force.
To pull the chariot\nOut of the mountain or abyss\nIs a task befitting the great man.
Leading his chariot,\nHe enters the ruins.
Escaping perilous terrain,\nHe ascends the hill.\nThere he is brought an ox.
Failing to pull the chariot free,\nHe cracks his ribs, cracking the axle.

High mountains tower.
Below, the river breaks in waves.
That man has an oar-drawn ferry.
With him you can cross.
Snakes lurk in the mud.\nAll are female. None are male.\nNone finally receive the gift.
Barring his storehouse door,\nHe secures the precious treasure.
The gate is shut but not bolted.\nThe golden key is thrown away.
Lifting our yoke or collar-bar,\nThe gain is slight. It benefits\nMinor expeditions only.

Mired in evil, barred from good,
He tries to pry us from our villainy
Which is hard as rock though not a rock.
Danger.
Safe behind his yellow walls,\nHe rests on golden mats.
Staggering,\nHe is barred from his sleeping mat,\nWhile someone sleeps securely in his house.

The Red Stench spreads to the passes.
If the Great King does not bar its way,
Contagion will sweep the kingdom
And drive his house.
Barring gates on an empty house,\nHe keeps it utterly empty.
In darkness, he makes himself small,\nBecoming consummately humble.
Self-deprecation, less than complete,\nHe clutches his cares to his breast.
Modestly done, his actions succeed.\nHe is a model for masters of men.
Taking penury as poverty,\nSome recklessly relieve it.
What the Earth empties\nRuns down to valley streams.
The small cup is filled to the brim.\nOnce full, it later topples.
To examine oneself when poor\nHelps make riches appear.
Though poor, he pretends he is not\nAnd so no one offers him relief.
Fine rain and drizzle\nMoisten parched gullies.\nIn three days, the valley is soaked.
Once the Void is deflected,\nThe heart inclines as well.
Straightening his belly,\nPulling up his back,\nHe achieves proper alignment.
He twists his belly\nIn straightening his back.
Husband and wife take separate ways.\nIt is the family they mean to preserve.
South by east, he aims at the ssu,\nBut north by west, his arrow flies.
Level, line, compass, and square:\nDifferent are their applications.
An unwomanly woman\nHas only herself in mind.\nShe overturns her husband's plans.
Killing and birthing oppose each other.\nHarmony and centrality he takes as his way.

The Green Sprite's wife lives apart
In a separate house of the sky.
If the pattern is broken,
The harvest's bounty fails.
Elevating his pure mind,\nHe blunts its bit-like sharpness.
Rising without roots,\nHis thoughts climb to Heaven.\nFalling back, he's stuck in the abyss.
Flying out from dark ravines,\nHe soars to lush trees,\nDrawn by their rare fruit.
Reaching ever higher, though unaligned,\nLike a plant, full-flowered without roots,\nHe wraps himself in empty fame.
Rising from the deep marsh, a crane calls,\nStepping up to Heaven, unashamed.
He ascends to the hall,\nHis upper and lower garments reversed.\nMen at court are dismayed.
He climbs the rickety tower\nSome prop it with wood.
Scaling the dangerous heights,\nSomeone axes the ladder beneath him.
Perched on a rotten stump,\nFirst he faces ruin, then finds a firmer base.
He cranks the drill,\nBoring into internal cracks.\nDanger.
At the first small signs,\nOppose and rectify.\nOnly apply the model decrees.
He gags his mouth with wood,\nAnd bolts tight the lock.\nThis is counter to propriety.
Critical words cut to the bone\nBecause the time is right.
He stupidly seeks a heap of sweets.\nSomeone hands him an unfired tile.
The trunk reaches to heaven.\nWith propriety comes prosperity.
When shouldered spears are many,\nConfrontations follow.
Fiery tongues inflame the city.\nHe sprays water from a jar.
Reaching for the floating clouds,\nHe forwith falls from Heaven.
From the time I crawled,\nI have loved this hidden virtue.
column8: It is as though I had not walked.

column7: Dazzled, his all-consuming greed\nDoes not help him gain his goals.
Warmed, the low grasses spread\nUp mounds and hills, as they should.
column8: The short look down on the tall.

column7: Pouncing on wine and food,\nHe battens but gains no renown.
For branching out, there is enough\nIf he trusts his sturdy carriage.
column8: His position is just as it should be.

column7: Branching out alone by leaps and bounds\nIs good for small things, but not for great.
column8: Expanding alone...\nCannot be turned to something great.

column7: In old age, the time comes\nTo bring to fruition what has been learned.
He is overrun with fleas and lice.\nDanger.
column8: Parasites are not worth trusting.

column7: Throughout, he proceeds as if\nOn the edge of an abyss,\nBound head and foot.
column8: He fears to meet with harm.\Beneath good fortune disaster crouches.

column7: Starting off wrong,\nThe path winds thereafter.
column8: Later it is hard to correct.

column7: From small defects he can return.\nHe can be taken as a model.
column8: He need not go far to set things right.

column7: Swerving from the path,\nHe cannot go straight.
column8: A straight course is impossible.

column7:
The circumstance contrives,
 the faulty seems correct.
Lucky men do not deem this
"happy coincidence"
The great Way is level,\nBut narrow byways\nDistress the grand carriage.

When the Great Void strays,
Some right it, some help it
Get back on course.
He finds men straight as arrows.
column8: He obtains worthy officials.

column7: To bend old truths\nIs to wander the road\nAnd go along with danger.
column8: There has never been one who could\straighten others by bending himself.

column7: Though twisting his foot,\nHe saves himself from a fall in the ditch.\nNow he faces the proper way.

The carriage axle breaks,
The yoke snaps,
The team of four tangles in its traces.
Men in high places spit blood.
Failing in small things,\nAttack them yourself\nAt the source.
column8: As yet, others do not know.

column7: Being steeped in his desires,\nHe brings about what he abhors.
column8: He is gradually led to error.

column7: "Might there be ruin? Oh, might there be?"\nThus he is led to the bright light.
column8: Shocked, he protects himself.

column7: Passing over small acts of goodness,\nHe will not overcome.
Having passed the gate, he returns\nTo enter, gaining the center court.
column8: Before going too far,\nHe reverses his course.

column7: In great hurry, he misses his gate\nAnd fails to enter his house.
column8: Truly, this is cause for grief.

column7: As with a pile of eggs,\nHe acts with great caution.\nFrom fear comes propriety, then safety.
column8: From his own danger, he creates safety.

column7: He stumbles forth on fettered feet.\nHis jaw is branded, his eyebrows destroyed.
column8: From one step into calamity, no return.

column7: Passing decrept city walls, he finds\nVerdant shoots rising from stumps.
column8: Through self-reform, life is renewed.

column7: The fatuous youth is not awake.\nMeeting us, he is blind and dim.
column8: A loutish youth who is unaware.\nWe fear he'll be "dark" 'til the end.

column7: He casts the sacred milfoil,\nHe fires the turtle's shell.\nLeaving the muck, he enters the anointed.
column8: He approaches the path of glory.

column7: The Eastern Star already shines,\nYet he cannot proceed by its light.
column8: The Eastern Star already shining\nMeans: Why not go?

column7: Some follow those in front.\nThose ahead light their way.
column8: Great is the light of those who lead.

column7: If in thick brush he seeks the ssu,\nHe finds a prize less valued.
column8: Hunting the ssu in the brush\nThe catch is not worth the praise.

column7: Open wide the tent,\nInviting guests from every quarter.
column8: Tent flaps up, the night sky comes into view.\nHe sees the many lights.

column7: Cultivating the puny\nHe becomes a runt.
column8: Making the puny grow\nThere is nothing to be achieved.

column7: Some beat him, some prod him.\nHe polishes mysterious mirror\nOf his mind. And so changes.
column8: Beating him and prodding him.\nIn that way, his errors decline.

column7: The young buck butts the wild ox,\nCracking its own skull.
column8: In return, it harms itself.

column7: Hearing aright, and increasingly silent,\nOutsiders fail to notice.
column8: Hearing aright, ever more silent,\nHe discerns what is inside.

column7: To increase his search for glory\nWithout squaring his inner life\nIs benighted.
column8: He only embellishes the outside.\n"Which is dearer, your name or your life?"

column7: Trees stay put,\nAnd so steadily grow.
column8: Rooted trees, gradual increase,\nThey cannot be suppressed.\nThe "way of wood".

column7: His waist cannot bear the load,\nYet others add to the weight on top.
column8: "Things fall apart,"\nThe center cannot hold\nMeans: He can be defeated.

column7: In marshes, being low makes for capacity.\nMany waters converge there.
column8: From self-effacement springs greatness.

column7:
Like a torch, the Red Chariot spreads its light.
One day increases our lists by 3000.
The noble man wins praise.
The petty man takes wounds.
column8: The petty man is no match for the noble.

column7: With height increased,\nCut back its peak\nTo make the mountain stable.
column8: With loss, all is accomplished.

column7: Enslaved by a handful of cowries,\nPast profits shave future gain.
column8: Enslaved for a handful of cash\nMeans: First happiness, then ruin.

column7: Jagged peaks do not collapse\nWhen they lean on their foothills.
column8: That rocky crags do not collapse\nMeans: Many knights give firm support.

column7: The crab skitters side-to-side, lagging\nBehind the worm in the Yellow Springs.
Focus on the One,\nThen nothing is unattainable.
Agitated, his focus is erratic.
If acute in timing,\nNothing is not benefited.
Penetrating East, he forgets the West.\nWatching his back, he overlooks his heart.

Acute in categories,
He holds within the Five Gauges
And Ten Thousand Measures.
He is tried and true.
Sharp for profit,\nDishonor and hatred set in.
Sharp when he ought to be sharp,\nHe saves himself from his own defeat.
High peak and steep bank\nCome tumbling down.
If kin are not close, their wills\nGrate like teeth in an uneven bite.
Trusting ties of flesh and blood,\nTo meet their goals they rely on kin.
The mulberry fly abandons its young.\nThe wasp that takes them on\nDoes not meet with disgrace.
Guests feel like kin in sharing rites\nWhen food and drink are properly measured.
Slighting those who deserve his care,\nHis closest friends shall run away.
Caring for those who deserve it,\nThe noble man grasps the Dipper.
However high and lofty his rank,\nHe is base in conducting affairs.
Dried meat shared with close kin:\nFlawlessly the noble man performs his duty\nTo act as trunk of the family tree.
Immature yet close: ill-omened.
Small taxes kept the same.\nHelp the common people feel secure\nAnd rectify the state.
Greedy hoarding, bit by bit,\nSteeps us in impropriety.
Seeing it is small, he eschews its use\nSo that we may fully develop.
Gathering profit & reducing punishment,\nSmall is the advance and great the retreat.
Livestock propagate contentedly,\nSnowy white cocoons blanket the fields.
Though small and weak at first,\nSomething big begins to grow.\nThe petty man fails to take heed.

The husband pulls in the cart shafts.
His wife peels wild and bitter herbs.
What benefits the king's paternal aunts
Does nothing for the common run of men.
An affliction.
Heavy taxes bring down the state.
Taxing in season,\nHelps forestall utter ruin.
To be hardheaded is not right.\nIt makes him utterly useless.
column8: One cannot confer with him.

column7: The phoenix spreads its wings in flight.\nNoble men approach the proper time:\nNo one can ever hold them back.
column8: Opportunity comes to the noble man.

column7: If pillars are uncentered\nAnd beams not high,\nThe great mansion is laid low.
column8: They cannot set the foundation straight.

column7: Keen of eye and ear, there and over there,\nHis attendants, left and right,\nOffer him staunch support.
column8: From every side, many knights approach.

column7: Noble men, when strong, use virtue.\nPetty men, when strong, use force.
column8: His faults increase as he gains rank.

column7: Using my strength to "overcome myself,"\nThe sky is the limit to what I can do.
column8: He displays great strength by yielding.

column7: Metal is strong but flesh is weak.\nBlood flows in the fields.
column8: Harsh laws cause great harm.

column7: He strengthens where he fails,\nMaking an effort where he is weak.
column8: Strong after failure.\n"Was mich nicht umbringt,\nMacht mich st√§rker."

column7: He uproots Mount T'ai,\nHe snaps pillars and beams.\nSuch men stumble and fall.
column8: In the end, he's undone by violence.

column7: Pure within,\nHe is clear, without stain.
column8: Gazing within, he finds\nHis conscience is clear and incorrupt.

column7: Tainted secretly, while feigning purity,\nHe is ashamed to the center of his self.
column8: A dark mix pretending to be pure.\nInauthenticity and self deceit.

column7: He lifts his eyes up to Heaven.\nHe lowers his ears to the depths.\nSuch is reverence.
column8: The innocent meet angels everywhere.

column7: The petty man envies the pure,\nAnd so loses rank and propriety.
column8: The Way is not attained.\n"Envy is a hate,\nAnd hate a subset of sadness."

column7: Pure to the "hidden yellow" core:\nSupremely stable, he knows no bounds.
column8: Pure in the hidden "yellow" mind\nHis model is the rectifying Earth.

column7: Great purity gives way to error,\nAnd so there is change.
column8: Purity succeeded by error\nThe petty man is overcome.

column7: In his purity, he sees his faults in time.\nThe noble man moves to repair them.
column8: He is good at mending errors.

column7: Pure evil, without a trace of good.
column8: Finally, he cannot be helped.

column7: Pure to the end and forever new,\nHe is propriety exemplified.
column8: Truly, this is cause for celebration.

column7: He prospers, but not by the line.\nHe loses secret virtue.
column8: Prosperous but unprincipled\nHe fails to conquer himself.

column7: Acts that do not depend on reward\nCan lead to great riches.
column8: Acts independent of ends\nThis we call "Mysterious Power."

column7: Love of profit fills the breast.\nIt does not profit the common good.
column8: For it builds private gates.

column7: With slight prosperity, subservience\nFunctions as a gateway for great men.
column8: Disregarding his own prosperity\nHe serves the worthy and humane.

column7: Failing to bear good fortune lightly,\nHe picks up ill and is then ensnared.
column8: Good fortune becomes heavy burden\nIn the way of a petty man.

column7: Granting him glory, Heaven\nOpens wide all borders to him.\nIn modesty there are rewards.
column8: Modesty increases what he has.

column7: As summer's fiery heat mounts up\nIt calls forth winter's icy springs.
column8: Triple fire.\nCalamity is not far away.

column7: He damps down the full blaze\nAs collapse is about to begin.
column8: Drawing off from the brim\nHe barely escapes from danger.

column7: The greatest prosperity does not save.\nCalamity is sent down from Heaven.
column8: Extreme fullness saves nothing.\nHeaven's Way is reversion.

column7: Not giving or receiving praise or blame,\nHe thus preserves his house.
column8: Unconcerned by the opinions of others\nHis Way is constant.

column7: The household has no flasks.\nThe wife supplants her elders.\nShe errs, washing them in mud.
column8: It lacks the means to carry on.

column7: With young and old in proper order,\nThe son can sustain the father.
column8: Sons carrying their fathers\nOnly then can there be renewal.

column7: A pig appears in the audience hall,\nWith a puppy following its tracks.
column8: Their presence is unlucky.

column7: Rudders and oars steady the ride.\nThey are good for riches and stability.
column8: Stable peace and harmony,\nThe ride is smooth to the borders.

column7: He who sets his well and stove apart,\nIn 3 years, only sees his family's back.
column8: Division into independent households\nMeans no feasts are enjoyed.

column7: The old man pulls a cart.\nThe young girl raises a jar.\nBoth benefit the ancestral house.
column8: Only then do their bodies grow strong.

column7: His stools upended, his ladles in pairs:\nHis household is no good.
column8: Family usage is not right.

column7: If the stump produces new shoots,\nIts kind is not cut off.
column8: Only then does its type last long.

column7: The model he builds is an unfit model.
column8: It is not worth using.

column7: He copies the model by centering,\nAnd so he overcomes.
column8: Being revered by all the masses.

column7: Failure to start with level and line,\nRuins his settings of compass and square.
column8: It is their use that is at fault.

column7: Level, line, compass, square--\nNone work against our applications.

The water jar is full.
The well is deep and wide,
In the end it cannot slake our thirst.

column8: The Grand Rule is made clear to us.

column7: If fine nets are cast on deep pools,\nThis does not benefit the fish.
column8: Tyrannical laws spread wider.

column7: He corrects those of us with faults\nUntil we have no depravity.
column8: He drives us on to perfection.

Water spills straight over.
With no valley or gorge,
It will end in a flood.

column7: Six, as trunk, sets the pattern,\nMaking Five, the branches, well-arranged.
column8: He adheres to the ruler.

column8: Otherwise, how could we think them correct?

column8: Warp and woof are properly placed.

column7: Setting nets and snares to catch us,\nEntangling lines stretch to the wilds.

column7: The dragon, in soaring to Heaven,\nRightly fears for its scales.
column8: At the peak, it fears a fall.

column7: Blazing heat is sustained in Heaven,\nWhile icy yin germinates in Earth.

This is right and good.

column7: Black Heaven meets Yellow Earth.\nTheir ideas interact, one upon the other.

column8: Neither going nor seeking.\nThis is the rule for gentlefolk.

column8: It truly is encouraging.

Comes upon a wasp.
However great the profit,
It cannot follow through.

column8: Coming to meet with his horns. Humiliation.\nStraight on the Way he proceeds.

column8: The empty stove means\nHe bears an empty reputation.

Its center bowl matches its size.
Still, they do not eat nor drink.
